events.title: Edict of Milan Proclaimed
events.description: Emperor Constantine and co-emperor Licinius proclaimed the Edict of Milan, granting religious tolerance throughout the Roman Empire, especially allowing Christianity to be practiced freely.
events.significance: Marked a major turning point for Christianity, accelerating its spread and eventual dominance in Europe.

events.title: Peasants' Revolt in England Reaches London
events.description: The Peasants' Revolt, a major uprising across large parts of England, saw the rebel forces enter London and confront King Richard II's government.
events.significance: Highlighted widespread social discontent and led to significant but temporary changes in labor laws and feudal relations.

events.title: Allied Forces Invade Rome During World War II
events.description: Allied forces captured Rome, marking the first Axis capital to fall during World War II.
events.significance: A crucial turning point in the Italian Campaign, boosting Allied morale and weakening Axis control in Europe.

events.title: Pope John Paul II Visits His Native Poland
events.description: Pope John Paul II made a historic visit to Poland, inspiring the Solidarity movement and bolstering opposition to communist rule.
events.significance: The visit energized the anti-communist movement, contributing to the eventual fall of communism in Eastern Europe.
